VOL. XVII, NO. 21.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 31, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

SUMMER SCHOOL OPENS JULY 1

TENNIS SCHEDULE ANNOUNCED

YOUNG.SCHOLARS OF THE WORLD

HOPKINS BASEBALL TEAM WINS

Courses Have Been Extended and the
Subject of Politics Inaugurated.
More Credits Given.

First Match Will Be With Georgetown
University at Homewood on the
Afternoon of April 12.

Eighth International Congress of Students to Convene in the United
States Next Fall.

Shows Improved Form and Defeats Wash ington College 11 to 6—Piep er's
Good Pitching a Feature.

The third annual summer session at the Johns Hopkins University will be held from July i to
August 12, 1913.
. The principal object of the University in making provision for the
, session is to furnish instruction to
teachers in all grades of schools,
and to other persons who seek opportunities for instruction, with or
without reference to an academic
degree. Some courses offered are
designed to meet the needs of matriculated students who wish to advance their standing or to make up
deficiencies; others, to enable .nonmatriculated students to absolve in
part the entrance requirements.
So popular was this branch of
the University last year .that 201
persons attended. The courses
were not only popular, but so thorough that the Board of Collegiate
- Studies has made it .possible this
year for a student to receive a maximum of one-half credit per course
ins:ead of one-third as heretofore.
However, of the courses given in
one summer session, matriculated
students or candidates for matriculation in the University may offer
for credit not more than two
courses in collegiate subjects.
The tuition fee is $25, payment
of which entitles the student tb attend as many as three courses.
The faculty of the summer school
consists of twenty instructors, of
whom four are women:

In view of the success of the
tennis team at Hopkins last season
and the interest this year displayed
on all sides, a most ambitious
schedule has been arranged for the
college team. Numerous challenges
were received, even from as far
west as the University of Michigan. Some of these offers had to
be declined because of the expense
involved, but the schedule, as finally
made up, is the best that the team
has ever had. In consists of seven
matches—three away and four in
Baltimore. The matches were arranged as much as possible for days
when a baseball game would not
interfere with the playing on the
courts.
As announced by Manager Corner, the dates are:
Saturday, April I2—Georgetown
University at Homewood (afternoon).
Saturday, April 26—Navy at Annapolis (afternoon).
Wednesday, April 30—Catholic
University at Washington (afternoon).
Friday, May 2—University of
Pennsylvania at Homewood (afternoon).
Wednesday, May 7—St. John's
at Annapolis (afternoon).
Saturday, May 17—Lehigh at
Homewood( morning).
Thursday, May 22—Haverford
at Homewood (afternoon).
Hopkins has never played Catholic University, Haverford or Lehigh before. •
As the groundkeeper has promised that the dirt courts will be
thrown open for playing early this
week, Captain Hammond will issue
a call for players in the very near
future. The men who played at
least once last year are: Belt, Dubray, Bacon, Hammond, Corner,
Springer, Angell and Hatch; of
these Dubray, Hammond, Corner
and Bacon are still at the University. It is plain that there is room
for several new players. Those
who practice steadily will receive
the preference at the time of • the
choice of the personnel of the team.
Undergraduates are to be given
every chance. Captain Hammond
is hoping that some talent will be
discovered in the lower classes.
Among the other men who are expected out this year are: Sears,
Lentz, Brady, Harrop, D. Penniman, G. Porter and Huck. Most
of the matches call for four singles
and two doubles.

For the first time in the history of international relations, the
United States will act as host to
the young scholars of the world
this fall, when the Eighth International Congress of Students will
take place under the auspices of the
Association of Cosmopolitan Clubs.
The official sessions will take
place on September 3-7, at Cornell
University, where the Cornell Cosmopolitan Club will throw open its
magnificent $50,000 clubhouse and
entertain the foreign guests in right
royal fashion. In addition, a comprehensive itinerary has been
worked out, beginning with the arrival of the delegates at Boston on
or about August 27, and ending
with their departure from New
York on September 16, which is
to comprise such features as a visit
to the historic spots of Boston
and Harvard University; a daylight trip on the Hudson from New
York to Albany; a reception at the
capitol of the Empire, State by
Governor Sulzer; an excursion to
"God's Grand Organ," the Niagara Falls; an inspection of
the university, the United States
Mint and the Curtis publishing
plant at Philadelphia; a • stay of
several days at Washington, with a
brillian reception in the Hall of the
Americas at the • Pan-American
Union, and a less formal reception
by President Wilson, and a final reunion at New York, with a banquet by the New York Peace Society.
The object of the congress, as
set forth in the "call" recently issued, is "to bring together the representatives from all the students
of the world, in order that the
spirit of international brotherhood
and humanity may be fostered
among them as a result of the deliberations of the congress, and in
order that the students of the
world may be united into an allembracing world organization."
The congress committee has received considerable material support from the -Division for Intercourse and Education of the Carnegie Foundation, which granted
a subvention of $2,500 to finance
the undertaking, and from the
World Peace Foundation of Boston. An\,. organization that has
for its aim the promotion of friendship and mutual understanding of
students from different countries is
cordially invited to send delegates.
We hope that Hopkins will send
a delegation.

The baseball team had but slight
difficulty with the Washington College nine on Saturday, and defeated
them by the score of i i to 6. Although there were many errors and
a great deal of ragged fielding, yet
the team as a whore showed marked
improvement over, the form displayed against Pennsylvania last
Tuesday. This was particularly
noticeable at the bat. Coach Hooper
has been giving the squad rather
strenuous batting practices and the
result was appreciably heavier hitting..
Hopkins gathered in three runs
in the fifth inning when Sutton
started off with a home-run. Williams was passed. Hobbs and Wilson both singled, and Williams and
Hobbs scored. Wilson, however,
was caught off third base and Hallock fanned, ending the inning.
Three of *Washington College's
runs came in the seventh. Frampton got to first on Hobbs' error, and
after Pearson had flied out to Webster, Lewis rapped out a two-bagger. Then an error by Hallock and
two more Washington College hits
contributed three. runs. But Hopkins came back in their half of the
seventh, and by means of singles by
Bagley, Rice and Sutton, and a
home-run by Hobbs, scored four
runs.
The only mishap of the game occurred in the second inning. Wallace, a Washington man, attempted
to score from third on an overthrow at first base by Pieper.
Hobbs' throw was accurate and
Rice caught his man a foot from
the plate. The latter's foot, however, as he slid, swung into the air
and cut a bad gash in Rice's-cheek.
But when he had been patched up,
Rice gamely kept on playing and in
the eighth inning rapped out a
single that was responsible for two
runs.
Pieper's excellent pitching was
easily the feature of the game. He
had perfect control, giving only two
free passes, while his opponent,
Bowen, who pitched seven innings,
passed eight men. In addition, he
struck out six men and only four
of the losers' six runs were batted
in, while of Hopkins' eleven runs,
seven were batted in.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 31, 1913.

Mr. Dickinson, editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER, who is convalescing at Atlantic City from a
severe attack of illness, is expected
back this Wednesday. Until he returns, the editing of this paper will
be in charge (34 a member of the
Board.
Naval Training.

T h e announcement from the
Navy Department that it will train
a limited number of college students on board battleships opens a
unique and profitable way to spend
two months of the summer vacation. The promise of keeping students of the same institution together assures congenial companions. As it is probable that not
more than twenty from Johns Hopkins will avail themselves of this
opportunity, there is no chance of
a small surplus of men being put
on a separate vessel. Two students
from the group, recommended
either by the college authorities or
the students themselves, will be in
charge of the squad. Over all will
be a naval officer. The men will
not enlist, but must bind themselves to obey the laws and regulations of the Navy. Regular uniforms will be worn, with civilian
clothes while on unofficial shore
leave. The fleet will rendezvous at
Naragansett Bay, spending one
week in port and one at sea. Although the week at port is by no
means an idle one, the week at sea
should be more enjoyable, as the
frequent fogs and occasional gales
off the New England Coast make
the trip very realistic. Later on in
the summer the fleet goes to Hampton Roads, where the fleet is divided and a war game played.

Instruction will be given as far
as possible along the lines which
the individual has taken up at college. Instead of giving a smattering of knowledge about many diverse subjects the men will receive
thorough ground - work in o n e
branch.
For stuaents in the "tech" there
is an invaluable opportunity for
first hand experience with machinery. The expense for uniform
and outfit will be $22, while the
board for two months will amount
to about $26. Naval training expense will also be borne by the students until a fund has been appropriated for Naval Reserve purposes.
As the government is back of the
plan with its ardent endeavors to
build up a Naval Reserve, and especially to improve the personnel
of this reserve, undoubtedly, the expenses will be kept down- to a minimum. Although we are told frankly that it is to be no summer excursion nor yachting expedition and
a slight expense will be incurred,
surely the benefit to the nation and
the individual will be enough compensation. Students desiring to become a member of the party from
Johns Hopkins should address their
application to the executive committee of the University, which will
decide on the personnel next week.
Application has already been made
by several of the undergraduates.

wisdom has seen fit to take from us
our beloved classmate, Katharine
Huntington Newton; and
Whereas, We had all learned to
love and esteem her for her womanly character, for her kindly nature and for her broad sympathies;
and
Whereas, We realize that by her
death we have sustained an irreparable loss and the medical profession
has been denied a student whose
spirit and application would have
served it well; and
Whereas, We feel the deepest
sympathy for her family in their bereavement; be it
Resolved, That we, the members
of her class accept and humbly reconcile ourselves to the Divine Will;
and be it further
Resolved, That we make a public
expression of our own sense of loss
and our heartfelt sympathy for her
parents and family; and be it further
Resolved, That a copy of these
resolutions be sent to her family."
JOSEPH S. LAWRENCE,
M. W. KING,
ROBERT W.JOHNSON, JR.,
C. LEE MCCARTHY,
ISABEL M. WASON,
W. P. FINNEY, JR.,
Committee for the Class.
Miss Newton was a member of
the first year class of the Medical
School. She received the degree of
bachelor of arts from Mt. Holyoke
in 1912. Her home was in Durham, Ct.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 31, 1913.
The Musical Clubs.

The Musical Clubs of the University settled down to work again immediately upon returning to school
after the Easter recess. Several
rehearsals were held last week.
Last Friday evening the clubs journeyed to the Lyceum Theatre at
Sparrows Point, where they gave
a concert to one of the largest audiences that have attended their
concerts anywhere. They seemed
to enjoy the program all the way
through, and showed their appreciation. After the concert, the young
people enjoyed an informal dance.
The floor was not as smooth as it
might have been, but the girls were
pretty and the music good, and
everyone seemed loath to stop dancing- when the time came to catch
the last car home. Definite reports
as to the financial success of the
concert have not yet been received.
Last Saturday, after the games
at Homewood, the musicians met
and took A train for Port Deposit.
There they gave a concert under
the sheltering roof of the Tome
School. The traditional hospitality
of this institution became evident to
all and it it is hoped that the concert may have helped to interest
Tome students in the Johns Hopkins University.
On April 4 the clubs will give a
concert at Forest Park. So far

Dr. Fine Suggested for Head of University

One of the men who are being
considered for the presidency of
the University became known on
March 21. Prof. Henry Burchard
Fine, dean of the department of
science at Princeton, was offered
the embassy at Berlin, but was undecided whether to accept or not,
since "he is being strongly urged
for the presidency of the Johns
Hopkins University." Dr. Remsen
has confirmed the rumor that Dr.
Fine's name is being considered,
but he has also emphatically stated
that no offer, tentative or otherwise,
had,been made to Dr. Fine.
Dr. Fine graduated at Princeton
in 1882 and was dean of the faculty while President Wilson was
president of the university. He is
distinguished for his work in science and mathematics. At present
he is abroad on a leave of absence
of one year.
There are only 50 Smiths in
Harvard. The Browns run second
with 24.
The University of the State of
Washington has the distinction of
having a co-ed cheer leader.

ERSITY OF TORONTO.

Spring must certainly be close
upon us when we are beginning tb
hear talk of the annual lacrosse
tour which our team takes through
the United States in the spring.
Last year the team was very successful. Not only did they win a
big majority of their games, but
they beat Swarthmore College,
Philadelphia, champions of t h e
American Intercollegiate League,
by a score of 6-2, and so brought
11 o m e the international college
championship.
This year they are planning a
more extensive trip, and will meet
the following colleges and clubs
of the northern States: Hobart University, Geneva, N. Y.; Cornell,
Ithaca.; Crescent A. A., Brooklyn,
two games; and Boston A. A.
Negotiations are also being carried
on with Carlisle Indians, Johns
Hopkins, Swarthmore and Mount
Washington A. C.
The tour will occupy thout three
weeks' time. The team will leave
on May 23, and play their first
game against Hobart on the 24th.
While playing the Crescents, they
will be the guests of that club, and
will spend five or six days at their
summer quarters on the Hudson
River.-7'hc Varsity.
UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA.

At a meeting of lacrosse enthusiasts recently L. E. Brion, Wh. '14,
and M. E. Graham, Arch. '14, were
elected captain and manager, respectively, of the proposed lacrosse
team. The elections were made
now because of the refusal of the
Allied Sports Committee to ratify
the establishment of lacrosse as a
recognized minor sport until a captain, manager and tentative schedule had been selected.
While there are many .experienced lacrosse players in college,
experience is by no means necessary, as a chance will be given
all men to learn the game and
grow up with it. Practice will
be held on Museum Field and it is
hoped that Franklin Field can be
obtained for scheduled games.
The management should have no
difficulty in arranging games with
other colleges, for the great Canadian game is well established at Harvard, Cornell, Swarthmore, Johns
Hopkins, Columbia, Hobart, West
Point, Annapolis, C. C. N. Y. and
Stevens.
The sport was recognized at
Pennsylvania until six years ago,
when it was dropped because of
lack of suitable practice field.—The
Pennsylvanian.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 31,

1913.

ORATORICAL PEACE CONTEST
J. Earle Uhler Selected as Hopkins'
Representative on April 4—To Be
Held in McCoy Hall.

The try-outs for the Oratorical
Peace Contest were held at I
o'clock on March II. Quite a number of contestants appeared, but
after several rounds of speaking
Messrs. Carter and J. E. Uhler
were selected as the two best. Of
these Mr. Uhler was finally chosen
to represent Hopkins on the night
of April 4. Several other Maryland colleges will send representatives, among them are Georgetown,
Washington and Loyola. Mr.
Harry Richmond has charge of the
arrangements. Those who desire
cards of invitation to the contest
on Friday, April 4, should see one
of the following invitation committee: Messrs: Hammond, '14;
Schmied, '13; Nachlas, '14; Uhler,
'15; and Spieker,'16. Special musical features have been arranged for
the program. The judges will be
Messrs. J. Barry Mahool, T. H.
Bowles, George R. Gaither, Alfred
S. Niles and William H. Morriss.
The reception committee consists of
Messrs. Weber, Nachlas, Hollyday,
Chenoweth and Branham.
This contest is held under the
auspices of the Grotius Society.
This society seems destined to
broaden its scope and increase its
membership. Plans are being made
for the production of a play. A
week after the Peace Contest the
Grotius Society will meet the Zelosophic Society of the University of
Pennsylvania in Baltimore to debate on the question of compulsory
industrial arbitration. The debating
team of the society 'consists of
Messrs. Rusk; Tingley; Schulman;
Nachlas, alternate; and Gminder,
adviser. The committees to take
charge o: this debate will be announced later.
LAST COTILLON ON APRIL 5
Will Be Held on Saturday So as Not to
Interfere With the Training of
the Athletic Teams.

The Cotillon Committee has gone
to great trouble to insure a great
success at the last cotillon of the
year. Saturday evening, April 5,
has been chosen as the best date,
because the athletic teams of the
University will not then have their
training interfered with. Moreover, on that day, both the lacrosse
and baseball teams play at home
and the track team has no meet.
C. Ellis Ellicott is treasure! of
the Cotillon Board and is prepared
to issue tickets of admission for the
night of the dance.
The chaperones who will receive
are: Mrs. Basil Gildersleeve, Mrs.
Miles White and Mrs. J. Whitridge
Williams.
Prof. Paul Haupt of the University was elected president of the
American Oriental Society at the
epening session of that organization's annual convention in Philadelphia on March 25.

GEOLOGY CLASS VISITS MINES
Half of Class Took Trip During Earlier
Holidays—The Rest Will
Go in June.

Dr. Charles K. Swartz, collegiate
professor of geology, and fifteen
students in Geology I returned Saturday afternoon at six o'clock from
the annual tour of Western Maryland which began Easter Monday.
Only half of the class went on the
trip. The other section will cover
the same ground after the graduation exercises in June.
The first stop was at Blue Ridge
Summit. A bus was taken to Monterey, and after looking around a
little Dr. Swartz led the way to a
little spring where the party ate the
lunches it had brought with them.
In the afternoon an abandoned copper mine was visited. Waynesboro
was the stopping place the first
night.
The next day Pen-Mar and High
Rock were visited and the party

Subject of Politics Inaugurated.

The third annual summer session at the Johns Hopkins University will be held from July i to
August 12, 1913.
. The principal object of the University in making provision for the
, session is to furnish instruction to
teachers in all grades of schools,
and to other persons who seek opportunities for instruction, with or
without reference to an academic
degree. Some courses offered are
designed to meet the needs of matriculated students who wish to advance their standing or to make up
deficiencies; others, to enable .nonmatriculated students to absolve in
part the entrance requirements.
So popular was this branch of
the University last year .that 201
persons attended. The courses
were not only popular, but so thorough that the Board of Collegiate
- Studies has made it .possible this
year for a student to receive a maximum of one-half credit per course
ins:ead of one-third as heretofore.
However, of the courses given in
one summer session, matriculated
students or candidates for matriculation in the University may offer
for credit not more than two
courses in collegiate subjects.
The tuition fee is $25, payment
of which entitles the student tb attend as many as three courses.
The faculty of the summer school
consists of twenty instructors, of
whom four are women:

In view of the success of the
tennis team at Hopkins last season
and the interest this year displayed
on all sides, a most ambitious
schedule has been arranged for the
college team. Numerous challenges
were received, even from as far
west as the University of Michigan. Some of these offers had to
be declined because of the expense
involved, but the schedule, as finally
made up, is the best that the team
has ever had. In consists of seven
matches—three away and four in
Baltimore. The matches were arranged as much as possible for days
when a baseball game would not
interfere with the playing on the
courts.
As announced by Manager Corner, the dates are:
Saturday, April I2—Georgetown
University at Homewood (afternoon).
Saturday, April 26—Navy at Annapolis (afternoon).
Wednesday, April 30—Catholic
University at Washington (afternoon).
Friday, May 2—University of
Pennsylvania at Homewood (afternoon).
Wednesday, May 7—St. John's
at Annapolis (afternoon).
Saturday, May 17—Lehigh at
Homewood( morning).
Thursday, May 22—Haverford
at Homewood (afternoon).
Hopkins has never played Catholic University, Haverford or Lehigh before. •
As the groundkeeper has promised that the dirt courts will be
thrown open for playing early this
week, Captain Hammond will issue
a call for players in the very near
future. The men who played at
least once last year are: Belt, Dubray, Bacon, Hammond, Corner,
Springer, Angell and Hatch; of
these Dubray, Hammond, Corner
and Bacon are still at the University. It is plain that there is room
for several new players. Those
who practice steadily will receive
the preference at the time of • the
choice of the personnel of the team.
Undergraduates are to be given
every chance. Captain Hammond
is hoping that some talent will be
discovered in the lower classes.
Among the other men who are expected out this year are: Sears,
Lentz, Brady, Harrop, D. Penniman, G. Porter and Huck. Most
of the matches call for four singles
and two doubles.

For the first time in the history of international relations, the
United States will act as host to
the young scholars of the world
this fall, when the Eighth International Congress of Students will
take place under the auspices of the
Association of Cosmopolitan Clubs.
The official sessions will take
place on September 3-7, at Cornell
University, where the Cornell Cosmopolitan Club will throw open its
magnificent $50,000 clubhouse and
entertain the foreign guests in right
royal fashion. In addition, a comprehensive itinerary has been
worked out, beginning with the arrival of the delegates at Boston on
or about August 27, and ending
with their departure from New
York on September 16, which is
to comprise such features as a visit
to the historic spots of Boston
and Harvard University; a daylight trip on the Hudson from New
York to Albany; a reception at the
capitol of the Empire, State by
Governor Sulzer; an excursion to
"God's Grand Organ," the Niagara Falls; an inspection of
the university, the United States
Mint and the Curtis publishing
plant at Philadelphia; a • stay of
several days at Washington, with a
brillian reception in the Hall of the
Americas at the • Pan-American
Union, and a less formal reception
by President Wilson, and a final reunion at New York, with a banquet by the New York Peace Society.
The object of the congress, as
set forth in the "call" recently issued, is "to bring together the representatives from all the students
of the world, in order that the
spirit of international brotherhood
and humanity may be fostered
among them as a result of the deliberations of the congress, and in
order that the students of the
world may be united into an allembracing world organization."
The congress committee has received considerable material support from the -Division for Intercourse and Education of the Carnegie Foundation, which granted
a subvention of $2,500 to finance
the undertaking, and from the
World Peace Foundation of Boston. An\,. organization that has
for its aim the promotion of friendship and mutual understanding of
students from different countries is
cordially invited to send delegates.
We hope that Hopkins will send
a delegation.

The baseball team had but slight
difficulty with the Washington College nine on Saturday, and defeated
them by the score of i i to 6. Although there were many errors and
a great deal of ragged fielding, yet
the team as a whore showed marked
improvement over, the form displayed against Pennsylvania last
Tuesday. This was particularly
noticeable at the bat. Coach Hooper
has been giving the squad rather
strenuous batting practices and the
result was appreciably heavier hitting..
Hopkins gathered in three runs
in the fifth inning when Sutton
started off with a home-run. Williams was passed. Hobbs and Wilson both singled, and Williams and
Hobbs scored. Wilson, however,
was caught off third base and Hallock fanned, ending the inning.
Three of *Washington College's
runs came in the seventh. Frampton got to first on Hobbs' error, and
after Pearson had flied out to Webster, Lewis rapped out a two-bagger. Then an error by Hallock and
two more Washington College hits
contributed three. runs. But Hopkins came back in their half of the
seventh, and by means of singles by
Bagley, Rice and Sutton, and a
home-run by Hobbs, scored four
runs.
The only mishap of the game occurred in the second inning. Wallace, a Washington man, attempted
to score from third on an overthrow at first base by Pieper.
Hobbs' throw was accurate and
Rice caught his man a foot from
the plate. The latter's foot, however, as he slid, swung into the air
and cut a bad gash in Rice's-cheek.
But when he had been patched up,
Rice gamely kept on playing and in
the eighth inning rapped out a
single that was responsible for two
runs.
Pieper's excellent pitching was
easily the feature of the game. He
had perfect control, giving only two
free passes, while his opponent,
Bowen, who pitched seven innings,
passed eight men. In addition, he
struck out six men and only four
of the losers' six runs were batted
in, while of Hopkins' eleven runs,
seven were batted in.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 31, 1913.

Mr. Dickinson, editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER, who is convalescing at Atlantic City from a
severe attack of illness, is expected
back this Wednesday. Until he returns, the editing of this paper will
be in charge (34 a member of the
Board.
Naval Training.

T h e announcement from the
Navy Department that it will train
a limited number of college students on board battleships opens a
unique and profitable way to spend
two months of the summer vacation. The promise of keeping students of the same institution together assures congenial companions. As it is probable that not
more than twenty from Johns Hopkins will avail themselves of this
opportunity, there is no chance of
a small surplus of men being put
on a separate vessel. Two students
from the group, recommended
either by the college authorities or
the students themselves, will be in
charge of the squad. Over all will
be a naval officer. The men will
not enlist, but must bind themselves to obey the laws and regulations of the Navy. Regular uniforms will be worn, with civilian
clothes while on unofficial shore
leave. The fleet will rendezvous at
Naragansett Bay, spending one
week in port and one at sea. Although the week at port is by no
means an idle one, the week at sea
should be more enjoyable, as the
frequent fogs and occasional gales
off the New England Coast make
the trip very realistic. Later on in
the summer the fleet goes to Hampton Roads, where the fleet is divided and a war game played.

Instruction will be given as far
as possible along the lines which
the individual has taken up at college. Instead of giving a smattering of knowledge about many diverse subjects the men will receive
thorough ground - work in o n e
branch.
For stuaents in the "tech" there
is an invaluable opportunity for
first hand experience with machinery. The expense for uniform
and outfit will be $22, while the
board for two months will amount
to about $26. Naval training expense will also be borne by the students until a fund has been appropriated for Naval Reserve purposes.
As the government is back of the
plan with its ardent endeavors to
build up a Naval Reserve, and especially to improve the personnel
of this reserve, undoubtedly, the expenses will be kept down- to a minimum. Although we are told frankly that it is to be no summer excursion nor yachting expedition and
a slight expense will be incurred,
surely the benefit to the nation and
the individual will be enough compensation. Students desiring to become a member of the party from
Johns Hopkins should address their
application to the executive committee of the University, which will
decide on the personnel next week.
Application has already been made
by several of the undergraduates.

Resolutions of Condolence.

"Whereas, Almighty God in His
wisdom has seen fit to take from us
our beloved classmate, Katharine
Huntington Newton; and
Whereas, We had all learned to
love and esteem her for her womanly character, for her kindly nature and for her broad sympathies;
and
Whereas, We realize that by her
death we have sustained an irreparable loss and the medical profession
has been denied a student whose
spirit and application would have
served it well; and
Whereas, We feel the deepest
sympathy for her family in their bereavement; be it
Resolved, That we, the members
of her class accept and humbly reconcile ourselves to the Divine Will;
and be it further
Resolved, That we make a public
expression of our own sense of loss
and our heartfelt sympathy for her
parents and family; and be it further
Resolved, That a copy of these
resolutions be sent to her family."
JOSEPH S. LAWRENCE,
M. W. KING,
ROBERT W.JOHNSON, JR.,
C. LEE MCCARTHY,
ISABEL M. WASON,
W. P. FINNEY, JR.,
Committee for the Class.
Miss Newton was a member of
the first year class of the Medical
School. She received the degree of
bachelor of arts from Mt. Holyoke
in 1912. Her home was in Durham, Ct.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 31, 1913.
The Musical Clubs.

The Musical Clubs of the University settled down to work again immediately upon returning to school
after the Easter recess. Several
rehearsals were held last week.
Last Friday evening the clubs journeyed to the Lyceum Theatre at
Sparrows Point, where they gave
a concert to one of the largest audiences that have attended their
concerts anywhere. They seemed
to enjoy the program all the way
through, and showed their appreciation. After the concert, the young
people enjoyed an informal dance.
The floor was not as smooth as it
might have been, but the girls were
pretty and the music good, and
everyone seemed loath to stop dancing- when the time came to catch
the last car home. Definite reports
as to the financial success of the
concert have not yet been received.
Last Saturday, after the games
at Homewood, the musicians met
and took A train for Port Deposit.
There they gave a concert under
the sheltering roof of the Tome
School. The traditional hospitality
of this institution became evident to
all and it it is hoped that the concert may have helped to interest
Tome students in the Johns Hopkins University.
On April 4 the clubs will give a
concert at Forest Park. So far

Dr. Fine Suggested for Head of University

One of the men who are being
considered for the presidency of
the University became known on
March 21. Prof. Henry Burchard
Fine, dean of the department of
science at Princeton, was offered
the embassy at Berlin, but was undecided whether to accept or not,
since "he is being strongly urged
for the presidency of the Johns
Hopkins University." Dr. Remsen
has confirmed the rumor that Dr.
Fine's name is being considered,
but he has also emphatically stated
that no offer, tentative or otherwise,
had,been made to Dr. Fine.
Dr. Fine graduated at Princeton
in 1882 and was dean of the faculty while President Wilson was
president of the university. He is
distinguished for his work in science and mathematics. At present
he is abroad on a leave of absence
of one year.
There are only 50 Smiths in
Harvard. The Browns run second
with 24.
The University of the State of
Washington has the distinction of
having a co-ed cheer leader.

ERSITY OF TORONTO.

Spring must certainly be close
upon us when we are beginning tb
hear talk of the annual lacrosse
tour which our team takes through
the United States in the spring.
Last year the team was very successful. Not only did they win a
big majority of their games, but
they beat Swarthmore College,
Philadelphia, champions of t h e
American Intercollegiate League,
by a score of 6-2, and so brought
11 o m e the international college
championship.
This year they are planning a
more extensive trip, and will meet
the following colleges and clubs
of the northern States: Hobart University, Geneva, N. Y.; Cornell,
Ithaca.; Crescent A. A., Brooklyn,
two games; and Boston A. A.
Negotiations are also being carried
on with Carlisle Indians, Johns
Hopkins, Swarthmore and Mount
Washington A. C.
The tour will occupy thout three
weeks' time. The team will leave
on May 23, and play their first
game against Hobart on the 24th.
While playing the Crescents, they
will be the guests of that club, and
will spend five or six days at their
summer quarters on the Hudson
River.-7'hc Varsity.
UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA.

At a meeting of lacrosse enthusiasts recently L. E. Brion, Wh. '14,
and M. E. Graham, Arch. '14, were
elected captain and manager, respectively, of the proposed lacrosse
team. The elections were made
now because of the refusal of the
Allied Sports Committee to ratify
the establishment of lacrosse as a
recognized minor sport until a captain, manager and tentative schedule had been selected.
While there are many .experienced lacrosse players in college,
experience is by no means necessary, as a chance will be given
all men to learn the game and
grow up with it. Practice will
be held on Museum Field and it is
hoped that Franklin Field can be
obtained for scheduled games.
The management should have no
difficulty in arranging games with
other colleges, for the great Canadian game is well established at Harvard, Cornell, Swarthmore, Johns
Hopkins, Columbia, Hobart, West
Point, Annapolis, C. C. N. Y. and
Stevens.
The sport was recognized at
Pennsylvania until six years ago,
when it was dropped because of
lack of suitable practice field.—The
Pennsylvanian.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 31,

1913.

ORATORICAL PEACE CONTEST
J. Earle Uhler Selected as Hopkins'
Representative on April 4—To Be
Held in McCoy Hall.

The try-outs for the Oratorical
Peace Contest were held at I
o'clock on March II. Quite a number of contestants appeared, but
after several rounds of speaking
Messrs. Carter and J. E. Uhler
were selected as the two best. Of
these Mr. Uhler was finally chosen
to represent Hopkins on the night
of April 4. Several other Maryland colleges will send representatives, among them are Georgetown,
Washington and Loyola. Mr.
Harry Richmond has charge of the
arrangements. Those who desire
cards of invitation to the contest
on Friday, April 4, should see one
of the following invitation committee: Messrs: Hammond, '14;
Schmied, '13; Nachlas, '14; Uhler,
'15; and Spieker,'16. Special musical features have been arranged for
the program. The judges will be
Messrs. J. Barry Mahool, T. H.
Bowles, George R. Gaither, Alfred
S. Niles and William H. Morriss.
The reception committee consists of
Messrs. Weber, Nachlas, Hollyday,
Chenoweth and Branham.
This contest is held under the
auspices of the Grotius Society.
This society seems destined to
broaden its scope and increase its
membership. Plans are being made
for the production of a play. A
week after the Peace Contest the
Grotius Society will meet the Zelosophic Society of the University of
Pennsylvania in Baltimore to debate on the question of compulsory
industrial arbitration. The debating
team of the society 'consists of
Messrs. Rusk; Tingley; Schulman;
Nachlas, alternate; and Gminder,
adviser. The committees to take
charge o: this debate will be announced later.
LAST COTILLON ON APRIL 5
Will Be Held on Saturday So as Not to
Interfere With the Training of
the Athletic Teams.

The Cotillon Committee has gone
to great trouble to insure a great
success at the last cotillon of the
year. Saturday evening, April 5,
has been chosen as the best date,
because the athletic teams of the
University will not then have their
training interfered with. Moreover, on that day, both the lacrosse
and baseball teams play at home
and the track team has no meet.
C. Ellis Ellicott is treasure! of
the Cotillon Board and is prepared
to issue tickets of admission for the
night of the dance.
The chaperones who will receive
are: Mrs. Basil Gildersleeve, Mrs.
Miles White and Mrs. J. Whitridge
Williams.
Prof. Paul Haupt of the University was elected president of the
American Oriental Society at the
epening session of that organization's annual convention in Philadelphia on March 25.

GEOLOGY CLASS VISITS MINES
Half of Class Took Trip During Earlier
Holidays—The Rest Will
Go in June.

Dr. Charles K. Swartz, collegiate
professor of geology, and fifteen
students in Geology I returned Saturday afternoon at six o'clock from
the annual tour of Western Maryland which began Easter Monday.
Only half of the class went on the
trip. The other section will cover
the same ground after the graduation exercises in June.
The first stop was at Blue Ridge
Summit. A bus was taken to Monterey, and after looking around a
little Dr. Swartz led the way to a
little spring where the party ate the
lunches it had brought with them.
In the afternoon an abandoned copper mine was visited. Waynesboro
was the stopping place the first
night.

Rock were visited and the party
